Now this I desire only to consider, that it was spoken in divers Languages; and if a man should write down my Expressions now, as they came from me, they would upon reading perhaps, appear not so well; so if these Expressions of mine should turn to Count Conningsmark's prejudice, as that I should Swear that this Phrase of killing or duelling was used, or that ever Count Conningsmark told me that he resolved to call, or that he would call him to an account, I might do him wrong perhaps, but if he should call him to account, what might be the Consequence of it.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir. Fran. Win.
SP.P: I would not intangle you, but only I would seek after the Truth. I do not ask you positively, whether he did bid you go to ask advice of the Swedish Envoy, that he did resolve so and so; but did he discourse it thus, if he should Duel him or Fight him.?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Hanson.
SP.P: As I am before God Almighty, I cannot say I heard such Ex∣pressions.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Williams.
SP.P: Pray Sir, you confess you acquainted the Envoy with it?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Hanson.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Williams.
SP.P: Did you bring the Envoy's Answer to the Gent. or no?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Hanson.
SP.P: If I should be upon the Gospel, I am sure I cannot exactly tell, what was the Expression.

SP.SPEAKER: L. C. Baron.
SP.P: What was it that you discerned he doubted, if he did call Mr. Thynne to account?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fra. Win.
SP.P: He spoke in relation to a Marriage, pray what was it?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Williams.
SP.P: What did that if relate to?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Hanson.
SP.P: If he should ask him satisfaction about it, having heard that he had spoken abusive words of him?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fra. Win.
SP.P: What then was to follow?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Hanson.
SP.P: If he should call him to account, then how the Laws of England might do in this Point?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Williams.
SP.P: To whom?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Hanson.
SP.P: To the Count.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Williams.
SP.P: What should befall him?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Hanson.
SP.P: Whether the Law should be contrary to him in the Design and Pro∣posals h might have, concerning the Young Countess of Ogle.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Williams.
SP.P: Well, I see you will give no reasonable answer to that; but now, when came the Polander over into England?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Hanson.
SP.P: I cannot say positively I can tell when he came.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Williams.
SP.P: But when did you see him first?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Hanson.
SP.P:
Upon the Friday he came and asked me for the Count at Monsieur Fauberts Academy. Now the young Count Conningsmark's Chamber and mine joyns
together, next to one another, and there came a man with him, I do not know his name, but if I see the man I know him.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Williams.
SP.P: You say the Polander came over on Friday?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Hanson.
SP.P: He came to me on Friday.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Williams.
SP.P: And he came to you to the French Academy, to enquire for Count Conningsmark?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Hanson.
SP.P: Yes, he did so.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Williams.
SP.P: Had he any Letters?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Hanson.
SP.P: Yes, he had two Letters.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Williams.
SP.P: From whom and to whom?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Hanson.
SP.P: I asked him if he had any Letter for Count Conningsmark, and he said no; but he told me he had two Letters, and the one was to the Count's Se∣cretary, and the other was to the Count's Steward in London. So I gave him back his Letters, and asked him whence he came; he told me, he was just come into England. I asked him, whether he had been a great while at Sea, and he told me, yes; and that it was Stormy, and he had like to have been cast away; said I, I hear you are expected therefore; have you paid your Lodging; no, said he; then said I, go and pay your Lodging, and come to me in the Morning early.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fran. Win.
SP.P: You say you heard he was expected, pray who expected him?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Hanson.
SP.P: The Count; for he had spoken formerly twice of the Polander, and in the great Storm thought he had been drowned. To the best of my remembrance, I have heard the Count speak twice of this Polander.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fran. Win.
SP.P: Of this man?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Hanson.
SP.P: I suppose it is the same.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fran. Win.
SP.P: You say you saw him on Friday?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Hanson.
SP.P: Yes, I did.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Williams.
SP.P: When did he speak of the stormy Weather? And that he was afraid the Polander might miscarry?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Hanson.
SP.P: About twelve or thirteen dayes before.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Williams.
SP.P: Now say as hear as you can what the Count said.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Hanson.
SP.P: He said the Polander was a mighty able man, and understood horses, and the Count had a mind to buy English Horses, and intended to have had this Po∣lander as a Groom to dress them after the German way, and no man was abler than the Polander to do it; and when he spoke of it, I went once to the Change, and in∣quired whether the Ship was lost.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fran. Win.
SP.P: By whose Directions did you go to inquire whether the Ship were lost?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Hanson.
SP.P: I had no Direction, but only Count Conningsmark's speaking about it.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fran. Win.
SP.P: He seemed to be concerned at it, did he?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Hanson.
SP.P: Yes, he was afraid that the Polander would be drowned.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Williams.
SP.P: You say you directed him to clear his Quarters?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Hanson.
SP.P: Yes, I did so.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Williams.
SP.P: Did you see him again the next day?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Hanson.
SP.P: Yes, he came the next day.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Williams.
SP.P: Was he the next day in Company with the Count or no?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Hanson.
SP.P: I brought him to the Count.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fran. Win.
SP.P: Where?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Hanson.
SP.P: It was a little before Noon; because I went the back way, and I left him at the Counts Lodging.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Williams.
SP.P: Did you leave him with the Count?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Hanson.
SP.P: Yes, I did.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Williams.
SP.P: Pray, as long as you were there, what passed between the Count and the Polander?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Hanson.
SP.P: I remember very well what passed between the Count and him, for I have thought of it. He spoke to him, and called him thou, as to his Servant, and asked him, where he had been all the while, and he answered he had been at Sea, tossed up and down.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fra. Withins.
SP.P: Pray what directions had you given about a Sword for that Polander?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Hanson.
SP.P: I went to the Counts Lodgings, and being desired by him to stay, I desired he would excuse me, for I could not stay, because I was to go about another Business; he told me the Fellow was all naked, and he had no man to send to buy him a Riding-Coat; I told him I would very willingly and heartily do it. And after I had dined, I went to an House near the Hay-market, and bought a Riding-Coat, and brought the Riding-Coat to the Counts Lodgings. I delivered it to the Count. Then the Count told me his Man had never a Sword, and I asked him how much his Lordship would please to bestow on a Sword, he told me a matter of 10s. or thereabouts; I told him I did not know where I should get such a Sword, nor how to send for it, because I was to meet his Brother, but I withal said, it is no matter for that, I will take care you shall have it; this Evening I went into St. Martins-Lane, but could not find ever a Sword worth a Groat. Then I went as far as Charing-Cross to a Cutler whom I knew, so I told him, Sir, said I, I have a Commission to bestow 10 s. on a Sword for a Servant, therefore said I, I leave it to your discretion, use my Friend well, and use your self favourably too. I asked him when I should have the Sword, he told me in the Evening; I told him I would call for it when I came from the Play, where I was to be with the Counts Brother. When I came back with the young Count Conningsmark from the Play I called for the Sword, but he told me it was not ready. I seemed to be a little angry, and told him that it was strange, a Gentleman could not get a little Sword got ready for him in an whole Afternoon. Well, Sir, said he, pray do not be impatient, I will send you the Sword, and afterwards he sent it to the Academy, and I afterwards sent the Sword to Count Con∣ningsmarks Lodgings.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Williams.
SP.P: Pray had you this Direction for the Sword, after you had brought the Polander to the Count, or before?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Hanson.
SP.P: Count Conningsmark did never give me any direction or charge to buy a Sword for him, but I did offer my Service if he pleased, because he said, he had no body to send.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Williams.
SP.P: Sir, You do not know the Question, or you won't ap∣prehend it; pray when had you this direction from the Count to buy this Sword?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Hanson.
SP.P: On Saturday in the afternoon.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Williams.
SP.P: When was it you brought the Polander to the Count?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Hanson.
SP.P: In the morning.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fra. Winn.
SP.P: Pray let me ask you another Question, when was it you first heard Mr. Thynne was kill'd?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Hanson.
SP.P: I heard it I believe about eight a Clock in the evening on Sunday.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fra. Winn.
SP.P: Had you any Discourse with the Count about the Murder?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Hanson.
SP.P: Yes, I had.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fra. Winn.
SP.P: Pray tell what that Discourse was?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Hanson.
SP.P: I was at Whitehall till ten of the Clock, and then I went to the Count; but I desire this may not be taken as an extraordinary Visit, because I used to go to him on the Sundays in the Evenings, and those 3 sundays before he was taken, I used to come to him in the Even∣ing, after I had been at Whitehall. When I came into his Lodgings, I found him in his Night-cap, and Night-gown; he asked me what News, I told him I could tell him great News, and that was of the killing of Esq Thynne, who was Shot in his Coach; The Embassador of Savoy had told me all that he had heard about it, and I told it him. After I had spoken of this Business, he asked me where his Brother was; I told him, his Brother was at the Duke of Richmonds. And after some Discourse I went away.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fra. Winn.
SP.P: When you told him of the Murder of Mr. Thynne, did he make no Answer, nor say any thing about it?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Hanson.
SP.P: He did not make me any Answer, by which I could con∣clude that Count Conningsmark was any way concerned in the Busi∣ness.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fra. Withins.
SP.P: Pray Sir, I ask you upon your Oath, the Count is a man of great Quality himself; When you told him of such an horrid Murder, what, did he say nothing about it?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Hanson.
SP.P: He asked me several Questions, what the People did say, but I would not make any mistake.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fra. Winn.
SP.P: Tell all he said Sir about it?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Hanson.
SP.P: I told him the greatest News I heard was, the killing of Mr. Thynne; and I told him who brought the News, and I told him the Court was heartily angry at it, that such an Accident should happen, and I said it was an Italian trick, not used in England.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fra. Winn.
SP.P: What said he then?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Williams.
SP.P: Pray do you remember what he said?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Hanson.
SP.P: What I have Answered now. He made me such Questi∣ons upon this story as I have told you.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Ch. J.
SP.P: Let him explain himself, pray as near as you can, relate what Discourse you had with Count Conningsmark, that Sunday night after you came to him and told him of the Murder.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir. Fra. Winn.
SP.P: What did he say to you?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Hanson.
SP.P: I will tell you my Lord; the Count was surprized as every man would be to hear of so sad an Accident, and so the Count asked me what the People said, so I told him what I heard at White∣hall, I cannot call to my memory all the Particulars; but I said the King was heartily sorry, and all the Court for so sad an Accident, and I must wrong my self or Count Conningsmark, if I should undertake to relate exactly what passed, for I cannot remember it.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. VVilliams.
SP.P: But you said just now, that you told the Count it looked like an Italian Trick, not used in England.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Hanson.
SP.P: Yes, I did so.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. VVilliams.
SP.P: What did he reply to that?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Hanson.
SP.P: Not a word.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. VVilliams.
SP.P: Did he mention any thing of Fortifications to you then?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Hanson.
SP.P: Yes, he gave me a Plain, or a Draught of a Fortification done with his own Hand, and that was all the discourse.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. VVilliams.
SP.P: So then he diverted the discourse to the business of Fortification.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Ch. J.
SP.P: The Evidence is heard, what it is that he ended all the discourse with, shewing him a Paper of Fortifications.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fr. VVin.
SP.P: But this he does say, He asked him what the people did say of it?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Hanson.
SP.P: For my Life I dare not say I remember any more than I have told.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Ch. J.
SP.P: Look you, Sir, now, will you in French deliver this, for the benefit of those Jury-men that don't understand English.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. VVilliams.
SP.P: We pray, my Lord, our Interpreter may do it.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Ch. J.
SP.P: When a Man can speak both Languages, he needs no Interpreter, he is his own best Interpreter.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. VVilliams.
SP.P: My Lord, I will tell you why I ask it; there is a great deal of dif∣ference, I find, where you examine a man with the Hair, and where you examine him against the Hair: where you find it difficult to make a man answer, you will pump him with Questions, and cross interrogate him to sift out the Truth; now if you leave this Man to the interpretation of what he hath said himself, he will make a fine Story of it, and we shall be never the wiser.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Ch. J.
SP.P: You may examine him in French if you will.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. VVilliams.
SP.P: And I understand none but Pedlers French.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fr. VVin.
SP.P: The truth of it is, what your Lordship says, cannot be opposed regu∣larly; but I do appeal to your Lordship, and all the Judges, and all the Court, whether this man does answer like an ingenuous man; you see he shifts.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Ch. J.
SP.P: I do not see it, nor do I believe any see he shifts in any thing you ask of him; either he tells you what the Question is, or the reason of it; how far that is a Reason, is left to the Jury to consider.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fr. Win.
SP.P: Certainly it can do no hurt to have an Interpreter.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Ch. J.
SP.P: North. My Lord, if there be two ways to take, 'tis best to take that which will give satisfaction to all Persons, let him be asked by the Interpreter, what Questions the Counsel would have answered, and then let him to tell his Answer in French.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Ch. J.
SP.P: If that be liked better, let it be so. Mr. Craven, can you tell the substance of the Evidence that this Gentlemen hath given?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Craven.
SP.P: No, I cannot, his Evidence has been so long, and so many cross Que∣stions have been asked.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fr. Win.
SP.P: I would spare your time—

SP.SPEAKER: L. Ch. J.
SP.P: But this is the way to spend our time.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fr. Win.
SP.P: I know your Lordship does not value time in such a case as this is, but you would have the Truth found out.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Ch. Just.
SP.P: You must repeat, first, the discourse you had with Count Connings∣mark.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fr. Win.
SP.P: My Lord, we will reduce it to two or three Questions. Mr. Craven, will you please to ask him what discourse he had with Count Conningsmark.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Craven.
SP.P: He says, the discourse he had with Count Conningsmark about the Po∣lander, was, that he came over as a Groom to serve him to look after his Horses; that he had occasion for several English Horses, and English Servants to look after them as Grooms; and among the rest of his Grooms, he intended the Polander should be one, to dress his Horses after the German way.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fr. Win.
SP.P: So far he goes as to that, That the Polander came over to serve the Count.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Ch. J.
SP.P: Look you, Sir, does not he tell you, the Count had a purpose to buy Horses here.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Craven.
SP.P: He says, there was a discourse about Bills of Exchange of 7000 Pistols to buy Horses.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir. Fr. Win.
SP.P: Pray then will you ask him, what discourse he had with Count Con∣ningsmark about the death of Mr. Thynne, and what the Consequences in Law might be.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Craven.
SP.P: My Lord, he says, that the discourse with Count Conningsmark, con∣cerning the Swedish Agent, was, That in case he should ask Satisfaction of Mr. Thynne, for the Affronts that he had given him, not understanding the Customs of the Nation, if he should call him to account, what prejudice it might be to him; for he did not hear, he says, that Count Conningsmark designed any thing, or resolved upon killing him, or any thing of that nature; but whether if he should call him to account, what the Laws of England might be.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Williams.
SP.P: Call John Wright.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir N. Johnson.
SP.P: My Lord, the Count desires to know if he may be permitted to make his Defence against these Witnesses.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Ch. J.
SP.P: No, he is not to make his Defence now. But pray tell him if my Lord have a desire to ask any Questions of this witness, he may ask what he pleases.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Ch. J.
SP.P: North. Let the Question be put to the Interpreter, that we may know what the Question is before the Witness gives an Answer.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Graven.
SP.P: He askes him if he has not seen him oftner in his Lodging undressed than dressed? And whether he was not to take Physick from his Physician.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Hanson.
SP.P: I do not remember that in all the time, I saw Count Conningsmark, I saw him dressed four times in his Coat, I cannot say I remember three times in all. The first time when he came he was in a Campaign Coat; but all the time he was in his Lodging, as I remember, he was in his Night-Gown and Cap. As to the other part of his Question, whether I heard that he took Physick? I say this, When I saw Count Conningsmark first at his Lodging; when I came to him, on the Sunday Even∣ing, I was told the Count was in Bed: It was late, but I ventured to go into his Room, and sat a quarter of an hour there; and afterwards the Doctor came in, Dr. Frederick, I saw him oftentimes at his Lodging; and at the same time the young Count was sick of an Ague: and when he came one Evening to see the young Count, I asked him what was the Distemper the Count had? the Doctor answered me, that he had not told any Body that the Count was sick, or what he was sick of, but he hoped in God in a short time he would be recovered.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Craven.
SP.P: He askes him if he gave him any positive order, that he should go of any Message to the Swedish Envoy.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Hanson.
SP.P: This I have answered before, and I say now, If this discourse that I had with the Swedish Envoy, turn to the Lord Count Conningsmark's prejudice, it would grate upon my Conscience all my life: Count Conningsmark never gave me any posi∣sitive Order to carry any Message; but I did gather, by his discourse, that the Count might be desirous to know the Envoy's Opinion about this Question; and therefore I thought the Count desiring it, I would do it to please him, rather than by Order. But I do not know that ever the Count had a mind to give me such an Order, but I did it voluntarily.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Ch. J.
SP.P: In plain English, Did he ever direct you to go to the Swedish Envoy?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Hanson.
SP.P: No, my Lord, he never did direct me.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Ch. Baron.
SP.P: How came you to chuse a Forreigner to know what the Laws of Eng∣land are?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Hanson.
SP.P: I thought it would please the Count to know his Opinion.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Ch. Bar.
SP.P: But how came you to chuse a Forreigner, I ask?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Hanson.
SP.P: He has been 19 Years here in England, and sure he should know.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Craven.
SP.P: My Lord, he asks him, if ever he told him that he had a design to fight Mr. Thynne, or do him any Prejudice, or send him a Challenge?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Hanson.
SP.P: My Lord, I am upon my Oath, and this I say, I speake it before God and the Court, Count Conningsmark did never tell me that he had any mind, or did resolve to call Esq Thynne any ways to account.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Williams.
SP.P: Call John Wright. (who stood up, and was Sworn.)

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fr. Win.
SP.P: We shall ask him but a Question or two, my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Williams.
SP.P: Pray tell me the time when this Polander came into England, that man at the Bar.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Wright.
SP.P: He came the 10th day of this Month.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Williams.
SP.P: Pray what Ship did he come in? where did you first meet with him?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Wright.
SP.P: Here in Town.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Williams.
SP.P: Where was it?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Wright.
SP.P: At the Cross-Keys in Throgmorton-street.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Williams.
SP.P: Pray when you first saw him; what did he ask you?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Wright.
SP.P: He asked me where Count Conningsmark's Lodgings were? I told him, I thought he was at Oxford, I meant the young Gentleman, for I did not know the other was in Town; but I went and enquired, and they told me, it was at Fau∣bert's Academy.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Williams.
SP.P: Whither went you with the Polander then?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Wright.
SP.P: I went to my Lord's Lodgings.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Williams.
SP.P: What Lord?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Wright.
SP.P: The young Count's Lodgings.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Williams.
SP.P: Well, and what then?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Wright.
SP.P: And I came to Mr. Hanson, and he did deliver a Letter to Mr. Hanson, and I stayed there about half an hour, or there-abouts.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Williams.
SP.P: When was this?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Wright.
SP.P: Upon Friday, the 10th day of this month.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Williams.
SP.P: How long was Mr. Hanson and the Polander together?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Wright.
SP.P: About half an hour.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Williams.
SP.P: What said Hanson to him in your presence?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Wright.
SP.P: Mr. Hanson said nothing.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Williams.
SP.P: Was there any thing said about going back, and paying his Lodging, and coming back?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Wright.
SP.P: Mr. Hanson came down to me, and told me, he was glad to see me, and bid me take the Polander back with me, and bring him to him to morrow betimes, for he must dispatch him about his Business.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fr. Win.
SP.P: Then he said nothing to the Polander?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Wright.
SP.P: No, but to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fr. Win.
SP.P: Well, what did you do the next morning?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Wright.
SP.P: I came to him the next morning to this Polander, and he took his things with him, which was a Sea-bed that he had, and a Gun with a Wheel-lock, and some other things.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fr. Win.
SP.P: And whither did you bring him?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Wright.
SP.P: I brought him to the upper end of the Hay-market, Monsieur Fau∣bert's School.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Williams.
SP.P: To what place did you come in the morning, say you?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Wright.
SP.P: Sir, if it please you, I brought him within a Door or two of Mr. Fau∣bert's the Horse-master, that teaches to ride the great Horse; for he did desire that we might go to an House hard by, because he would not carry his carriage to my Lord, he had a Sea-bed, a Portmantle, a Gun, and other things; and so I brought him to an House, and there I called for a Pot of Ale; and he put down his things and went out, I thought he had gone to make water, but within a little while after returns a∣gain, and Mr. Hanson comes in with him; he asked me why I did not come sooner? I told him, I had some other Business, I was with some French Merchants to look upon some Goods. So he bid the Pole pay me for my trouble, and take up his things, and go along with him; and he did do so, and I never saw the Pole afterwards.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Cb. J.
SP.P: You that are the Interpreters, repeat what he bath said to the Jury. (which was done.)

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fr. Win.
SP.P: We have done with this man, the use we make of him, is to follow this Polander, and we shall bring him to the Count by and by. Call Dr. Frederick Harder. (who was sworn.)

SP.SPEAKER: L. Ch. J.
SP.P: The Doctor understands English, don't he?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fr. Win.
SP.P: Yes, we are told he does.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Williams.
SP.P: How long have you known the Count that stands there at the Bar?

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Harder.
SP.P: I have known him a good while; it may be this four or five Years; I have known him four or five Years.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. VVilliams.
SP.P: How long have you known Captain Vratz?

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Harder.
SP.P: About a Year and a half, or two Years.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. VVilliams.
SP.P: Was my Lord and Capt. Vratz acquainted then?

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Harder.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Williams.
SP.P: Was he in employment under my Lord? was he in the Counts Service?

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Harder.
SP.P: He was with the Count, but whether he was his Companion, I cannot tell.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. VVilliams.
SP.P: Did he live with the Count?

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Harder.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. VVilliams.
SP.P: Did Capt. Vratz, when the Count came last over into England, come over with him.

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Harder.
SP.P: Yes, by my knowledg.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Ch. J.
SP.P: Do you know it or not?

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Harder.
SP.P: Capt. Vratz came to me, and told me, my Lord desired to speak with me, and I went with him to my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fr. Win.
SP.P: Was that the first Message you received from the Count?

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Harder.
SP.P: Yes, it was.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Williams.
SP.P: How long was that ago?

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Harder.
SP.P: The same day the Morocco Embassador did exercise in Hide-Park.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fr. Win.
SP.P: How long is that ago?

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Harder.
SP.P: About a month ago.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fr. Win.
SP.P: What, was that his first Lodging after he came last into Eng∣land?

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Harder.
SP.P: It was in the Hay-market.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Ch. J.
SP.P: Was it a corner House, as the other Witness saith, or not?

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Harder.
SP.P: Yes, it was.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Williams.
SP.P: Was the Count a private Lodger there?

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Harder.
SP.P: He lay in his Bed when I came to him; he came as a Traveller privately.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Williams.
SP.P: Did he go by his own Name, or another Name?

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Harder.
SP.P: No Body did question him about his Name, but when I did come to him, I did discourse him about his Body.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Williams.
SP.P: Pray Sir, thus; you went often to visit him, pray did you enquire for him by his own Name, or any other Name?

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Harder.
SP.P: He desired that he might be private, because he was to take some Me∣dicines, and he would not have it known.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Williams.
SP.P: Now Sir, I would ask you, did you observe him to be in any Dis∣guise? Did he wear a Perriwig, or how?

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Harder.
SP.P: He had a Perriwig.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Williams.
SP.P: Was it a fair Perriwig, or what colour?

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Harder.
SP.P: It was brown or black.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fr. Win.
SP.P: Sir, was he in a disguise, or no?

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Harder.
SP.P: He had his own Clothes, but he had a Perriwig.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fr. Win.
SP.P: Pray what Name did he go by, his right Name, or any particular Name?

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Harder.
SP.P: In the first beginning I gave him no Name, but said he to me, If any Body ask you about me, I would not be known; for if they know that I lie privately thus, they will think I ail some ill Distemper, therefore I would have you call me by the Name of Carlo Cuski.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Williams.
SP.P: Were you with him, pray Sir, upon the Sunday Morning that Mr. Thynne was murdered?

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Harder.
SP.P: I cannot certainly tell, but I was with him in the afternoon.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fr. Win.
SP.P: Pray call your self to mind, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Harder.
SP.P: I cannot certainly tell.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir. Fr. Win.
SP.P: What time were you with him in the Evening?

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Harder.
SP.P: At nine a Clock at night, or thereabouts.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Williams.
SP.P: Did you receive any Letter from Capt. Vratz at any time?

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Harder.
SP.P: I did, upon Saturday morning, the Saturday before Mr. Thynne was murdered.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fr. Win.
SP.P: Have you that Letter about you?

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Harder.
SP.P: No.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fr. Win.
SP.P: What was in the Letter?

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Harder.
SP.P: He desired me to go to the Count, who had a desire to speak with me. I came there and had some speech with him about his Indisposition; I told him he had better stay till next day before he took Physick, because it was cold Weather. And after that went with the Polander to my Lodging, and the Captains man came in, and then said, here is a man that will direct you to Capt. Vratz Lodging; which I did not know.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Williams.
SP.P: Look you, Sir, you say you went to the Count, Did you shew the Count that Letter from Capt. Vrats, or no?

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Harder.
SP.P: The Count saw it.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Williams.
SP.P: Then hear a little, When was it you shew'd the Letter to the Count? Was it Saturday or Sunday?

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Harder.
SP.P: It was Saturday.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Williams.
SP.P: Now, was the Polander then in the Count's Lodgings, or no?

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Harde.
SP.P: Yes, he was.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Williams.
SP.P: Was there any discourse about him then?

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Harder.
SP.P: I had never seen him in my life.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. VVilliams.
SP.P: But was there any with the Count?

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Harder,
SP.P: No, not at all.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fr. VVin.
SP.P: Then, upon your Oath I ask you once more, Was the Polander ever in Company with you and my Lord at any time?

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Harder.
SP.P: No.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fr. VVin.
SP.P: Upon the Sunday, upon your Oath?

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Harder.
SP.P: No.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fr. VVin.
SP.P: Nor the Saturday evening?

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Harder.
SP.P: No, I have not seen him since that morning when the Captains man took him along with him to his Master.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Williams.
SP.P: Pray how came the Polander into your company on Saturday morning?

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Harder.
SP.P: I had him from my Lords that morning.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Williams.
SP.P: Then my Lord and the Polander were together?

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Harder.
SP.P: No, they were not together.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. VVilliams.
SP.P: Was the Polander in my Lord's Lodgings?

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Harder.
SP.P: Yes, the Polander was below stairs.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. VVilliams.
SP.P: And did you take him from the Lodging?

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Harder.
SP.P: Yes, I did.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. VVilliams.
SP.P: How long did he continue with you?

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Harder.
SP.P: Not at all, I went home with him.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. VVilliams.
SP.P: Had you no discourse with him?

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Harder.
SP.P: No, none at all.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. VVilliams.
SP.P: Where did you part with him?

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Harder.
SP.P: I brought him to my House; and when he came in a Doors, the Cap∣tain's man being there, I told him there was a man would shew him the Captains Lodgings; and he took him away along with him.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. VVilliams.
SP.P: You say, the Captains Man had the Polander from you; pray name that man.

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Harder.
SP.P: I cannot tell his Name.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. VVilliams.
SP.P: Was his name Berg?

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Harder.
SP.P: I believe it was.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fr. VVin.
SP.P: You say you delivered a Letter from Capt. Vratz on Saturday morn∣ing to the Count?

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Harder.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fr. VVin.
SP.P: Did the Count read the Letter, and tell you the Contents of it?

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Harder.
SP.P: No, it was not sealed.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fr. VVin.
SP.P: Did not you know the Contents of it then?

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Harder.
SP.P: No.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fr. VVin.
SP.P: Pray, when you delivered the Letter from Capt. Vratz to the Count, what did the Count say to you?

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Harder.
SP.P: The Letter was not written to the Count, but it was writ to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. VVilliams.
SP.P: What was the reason that you shewed it to him then?

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Harder.
SP.P: I received a Letter from Capt. Vratz, that the Count desired to speak with me; and afterwards I was desired to direct this Man, the Polander, to Captain Vratz; and so I directed him to Capt. Vratz, and nothing more I know.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fr. VVin.
SP.P: Well, Sir, one thing more and I have done with you, for you will not, I see, give a reasonable Answer; pray, when the Polander came along with you from the Counts, did you observe he had any thing about him?

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Harder.
SP.P: He had a great Campaign Coat.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fr. VVin.
SP.P: Did he seem to have any thing under it?

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Harder.
SP.P: He had a Portmantle under it, I think, or some such thing.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Craven.
SP.P: My Lord, the Count desires to ask him some Questions.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Ch. J.
SP.P: Let him ask what Questions he will.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Craven.
SP.P: My Lord, he asks him whether he does not remember, when he first came to Town, he had not his Body full of Spots?

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Harden.
SP.P: Yes, my Lord, when he came from Tangier, he had spots over all his Breast; and it was feared they might get up higher towards his Neck, and indanger him very much.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Craven.
SP.P: He says, If my Lord pleases, he will shew it openly.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Ch. J.
SP.P: No, there is no need of that Goctor. Did you give him Physick for that?

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Harder.
SP.P: Yes, for that I did administer Physick to him.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Craven.
SP.P: He says, my Lord, he over-heated himself in riding to Tangier, thinking to do the King and the Nation Service, and the Heat broke out in spots over his Brest.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Ch. J.
SP.P: The Doctor knows nothing of that.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Craven.
SP.P: He asks, Whether the Doctor was not desired by him to cure him; whether he did not tell him he would cure him of those Spots?

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Harder.
SP.P: He desired me to administer Physick unto him?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Craven.
SP.P: He says, he went to Strasburgh, and when he came back, he was in the same condition he was in before; and he asks whether the Doctor did not undertake to cure him?

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Harder.
SP.P: Yes, I did administer Physick unto him; and this my own man can testify and be witness of; because my Lord bid me take care that he might be private, for he would not have it known that he did take Physick; but I told my man, said I, 'tis my Lord Conningsmark, and therefore pray take care of him, and see that the Physick be made very well up.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Ch. J.
SP.P: You seem to intimate, as if he lay private to take Physick, pray let me ask you this Question, Did you give him Physick all this time?

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Harder.
SP.P: Not always purging Physick, but some sort of Physick all the time?

SP.SPEAKER: L. Ch. J.
SP.P: What every night and morning?

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Harder.
SP.P: Yes, every day.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Craven.
SP.P: The Count desires to ask him where he was that unhappy day this Business was done?

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Harder.
SP.P: I found him that day ill, lying down upon the Bed, I asked him how his Physick had worked; he told me he was afraid he had got some cold; and indeed I found him very much disordered, and I went home and fetched him some Physick to take that night.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Ch. J.
SP.P: By the Oath you have taken, was there any other occasion, or had you any other discourse with him, when you came on the Sunday night, but concerning his Physick?

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Harder.
SP.P: My Lord, I will tell you the Truth; I never heard the Count speak any word in my life, that he had any concern, or design of any quarrel at all, nor any discourse, but about the administration of his Physick.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Ch. J.
SP.P: Let me ask you this Question, for they desire it here, What was the occasion? And whether you know the occasion why my Lord altered his Lodgings so often?

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Harder.
SP.P: The first occasion was this, Because it was in the Hay-market; and his Man said it would be quickly known if he did continue there; so he would take ano∣ther Lodging, which was in Buperts-street, and there he lodged three days; but the Chimney did so smoke, that my Lord could not stay, because he could have no Fire in his Chamber, and the weather was very cold, for it did Snow, and therefore I told my Lord, it was not so proper for taking of Physick: Thereupon he desired me to take him another Lodging in Queen-street, which I did look about for, but it was not rea∣dy, so he had a Lodging taken for him in St. Martins-lane, where he lodged till he went away.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Williams.
SP.P: Pray, Sir, the Physick that you gave the Count, did it require his keeping within doors? might not he walk abroad with it, upon your Oath?

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Harder.
SP.P: It did require him to keep in.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Williams.
SP.P: Pray then, how comes it to pass that the Count so suddenly could go by Water to Gravesend?

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Harder.
SP.P: I do not know what was done afterwards.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fr. Win.
SP.P: I would ask you one Question, and I would fain have you give me a fair answer to it, What became of the Letter that Capt. Vratz writ to you, and you shewed it to the Count.

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Harder.
SP.P: It remained there upon the Table.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir F. Win.
SP.P: Did not you keep your own Letter?

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Harder.
SP.P: It was not of any Concern.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fr. Win.
SP.P: If the Letter were written to you, it is not so long since, but you can tell us the Contents of it; pray what were the Contents?

SP.SPEAKER: L. Ch. J.
SP.P: Can you remember what were the Contents?

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Harder.
SP.P: He desired me to go to Count Conningsmark, who would speak with me; and that I would give his man an Answer when I came from him.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fr. Win.
SP.P: But what were you to go to the Count to do?

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Harder.
SP.P: Nothing, but the Count discoursed to me about his own Body and In∣disposition.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fr. Win.
SP.P: But Capt. Vratz was no Physician; why should he send you a Letter to talk about Physick?

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Harder.
SP.P: It was nothing but my Lord would speak with me.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Williams.
SP.P: We need not trouble our selves with this Fellow, he confesses he found the Polander in the Count's House.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fr. Withins.
SP.P: Pray, Sir, let me ask you, Who was with the Count on Sunday night?

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Harder.
SP.P: Mr. Hanson was there, I think.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fr. Withins.
SP.P: Who else?

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Harder.
SP.P: The Captain came in, and went out again.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fr. Win.
SP.P: What time of night was it that Vratz came in to the Count?

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Harder.
SP.P: It was at the same time that I was with him.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fr. Win.
SP.P: That he swears to be about nine a Clock; Was it after Mr. Thynne was killed?

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Harder.
SP.P: We had not heard it.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fr. Win.
SP.P: Sir, was it nine of the Clock?

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Harder.
SP.P: Yes, it was.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Williams.
SP.P: You say you found the Polanderat the Count's Lodgings?

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Harder.
SP.P: Yes, upon Saturday morning.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Williams.
SP.P: Then he came along with you from the Count's Lodgings?

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Harder.
SP.P: Yes, to my House.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Williams.
SP.P: And you parted with him there?

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Harder.
SP.P: Yes, the Captains man took him away with him.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Williams.
SP.P: That was Berg, wa'nt it?

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Harder.
SP.P: Yes.

DIV1.P: Then this Evidence was interpreted to the Jury.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Craven.
SP.P: He desires the Jury should know what the Doctor said about his Sickness.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Ch. J.
SP.P: Let it be repeated to them.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Craven.
SP.P: He desires to know whether he may not speak it in French himself.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Ch. J.
SP.P: No, the Interpreter must do it; (which was done.) My Lord, would you ask any more Questions of the Doctor?

SP.SPEAKER: Count Conn.
SP.P: No more Questions but them I have asked.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fr. Win.
SP.P: Call Thomas Howgood. (who was sworn.)

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Williams.
SP.P: Pray, did you sell any Sword to the Count?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Howgood.
SP.P: I sold a Sword to the Governor, a broad Horseman's Sword.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Williams.
SP.P: When was this?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Howgood.
SP.P: On Saturday was fortnight.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Williams.
SP.P: What time was it that he bespoke it?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Howgood.
SP.P: He bespoke it half an hour after six at night.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Williams.
SP.P: What did he say to you when he bought it?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Howgood.
SP.P: He said he would call for it about eight a Clock at night, when he came from the Play.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Williams.
SP.P: What kind of Sword was it?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Howgood.
SP.P: An Horseman's Sword, as broad as two fingers, such as the Gentle∣men of the Guards wear.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fr. Win.
SP.P: When he came for the Sword, what said he?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Howgood.
SP.P: He was angry it was not done, and I told him that I would send it to him quickly.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fr. Win.
SP.P: Where was it sent.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Howgood.
SP.P: To the Governor's Lodgings at the Academy.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Williams.
SP.P: Now, my Lord, we will call several Persons that were privy to the concealing of this Gentleman, that can give you a better account, Richard Hays and Robert French.

DIV1.P: (Robert French appeared, and was sworn.)

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fr. Win.
SP.P: Pray, will you tell my Lord what you know of the Count's concealing himself, and changing his Habit.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. French.
SP.P: I never saw him, my Lord, before I came here in Court, but it seems he did lodg in my House three or four days.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fr. Win.
SP.P: How long is it since?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. French.
SP.P: Between three weeks and a month ago, just ten days before the Mur∣der.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fr. Win.
SP.P: What Name did he go by then?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. French.
SP.P: I did not know his Name.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fr. VVin.
SP.P: Who used to resort to him at that time?

SP.SPEAKER: L. Ch. J.
SP.P: You say, Sir, you saw him not, what company did come to him?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. French.
SP.P: I did not see him indeed.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fr. VVin.
SP.P: Pray did Capt. Vratz come to him to your House?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. French.
SP.P: He lodged with him all the time.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fr. VVin.
SP.P: You say you know Capt. Vratz was there?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. French.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. VVilliams.
SP.P: Did Dr. Harder use to come to him?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. French.
SP.P: Yes, several times a day.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. VVilliams.
SP.P: What Name did he enquire for him by?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. French.
SP.P: The Doctor took the Lodging, and it was for a stranger, I heard no Name at all.

SP.SPEAKER: Interpreter.
SP.P: My Lord desires to know, whether you did not suspect he took Phy∣sick in the House?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. French.
SP.P: I suppose the Doctor did give you an account of that, I don't know that he did.

SP.SPEAKER: Interpret.
SP.P: Did not your Maid know of any such thing?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. French.
SP.P: My Maid is here, she will give you an account.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fr. VVin.
SP.P: Call Ann Prince; (who was sworn) Pray do you acquaint my Lord what you know of Count Conningsmark; whether ever you saw him at your Masters House in the Hay market?

SP.SPEAKER: Prince.
SP.P: Yes, he lodged there.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. VVilliams.
SP.P: When?

SP.SPEAKER: Prince.
SP.P: He came thither last Friday was a month.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. VVilliams.
SP.P: How long did he stay there?

SP.SPEAKER: Prince.
SP.P: Till VVednesday.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. VVilliams.
SP.P: At that time, who used to frequent his Company?

SP.SPEAKER: Prince.
SP.P: I know no Body but the Doctor that used to come to him.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. VVilliams.
SP.P: What Name did he go by?

SP.SPEAKER: Prince.
SP.P: No Name at all as I know of; they did not ask for him by any Name.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. VVilliams.
SP.P: Did the Captain use to come to him?

SP.SPEAKER: L. Ch. J.
SP.P: Her Master says he did lie there.

SP.SPEAKER: Prince.
SP.P: Yes, he used to lodg there.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. VVilliams.
SP.P: Did the Captain give him any Physick?

SP.SPEAKER: L. Ch. J.
SP.P: No, but the Doctor did.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fr. VVin.
SP.P: He only asks a merry Qustion.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Ch. J.
SP.P: But we are now upon the Life and Death of a man, pray let us have those Questions asked that are serious, not such light things as are permitted in or∣dinary Cases.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fr. VVin.
SP.P: Now, my Lord, we will call Francis VVatts.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Craven.
SP.P: Maid, my Lord asks, whether he did not take a Vomit in your House?

SP.SPEAKER: Prince.
SP.P: Not that I know of.

DIV1.P: Then Francis Watts was sworn.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Ch. J.
SP.P: How old is the Child?

SP.SPEAKER: Fr. VVatts.
SP.P: Fifteen Years old last Christmass.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Ch. Baron.
SP.P: Ask him whether he understands what an Oath is?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Thynne.
SP.P: He was sworn before the King and Council.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Ch. Baron.
SP.P: If he were sworn before the Council, he may give Evidence here sure.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fr. VVin.
SP.P: Were you at the Counts Service at any time.

SP.SPEAKER: VVatts.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fr. VVin.
SP.P: How long?

SP.SPEAKER: VVatts.
SP.P: I was with him eleven days; I came to him upon the Friday.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fr. VVin.
SP.P: How long was it before the Death of Mr. Thynne?

SP.SPEAKER: VVatts.
SP.P: I think it was ten days before the Death of Mr. Thynne.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fr. VVin.
SP.P: What was your Employment with him?

SP.SPEAKER: VVatts.
SP.P: His Boy to wait upon him.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fra. Winn.
SP.P: Did you lye in the same Lodging?

SP.SPEAKER: Watts.
SP.P: No, at my Fathers.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fr. Winn.
SP.P: What was the Agreement between your Father and the Count?

SP.SPEAKER: Watts.
SP.P: Six pence a day, and my diet.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fr. Winn.
SP.P: What Company did you observe came to the Count's Lodgings?

SP.SPEAKER: Watts.
SP.P: That Gentleman there in the black Perriwig.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fr. Winn.
SP.P: Was he often with your Master?

SP.SPEAKER: Watts.
SP.P: Yes, every day.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fr. Winn.
SP.P: How many Lodgings had he while you were with him?

SP.SPEAKER: Watts.
SP.P: Three: one in the Hay-market, and one in Rupert-street, and then the last in St. Martins.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Williams.
SP.P: Thus Child, Do you remember the time of killing Mr. Thynne?

SP.SPEAKER: Watts.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Williams.
SP.P: Were you in your Master's Service then?

SP.SPEAKER: Watts.
SP.P: Yes, I was.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Williams.
SP.P: Who was in your Master's Company that morning before Mr. Thynne was killed?

SP.SPEAKER: Watts.
SP.P: I came up, as I used to do in the morning, to my Master, and he aked me what was the matter with the bustle in the Street? and I told him some body was taken upon suspicion for killing Esq Thynne.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fr. Wynn.
SP.P: That was on the Monday morning; but the Sunday morning before, what Company did you observe there then?

SP.SPEAKER: Watts.
SP.P: I cannot tell any thing exactly of the Sunday morning.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fr. Wynn.
SP.P: Was Captain Vratz there?

SP.SPEAKER: Watts.
SP.P: I can't exactly remember.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fra. Winn.
SP.P: What time in the Evening was it reported Mr. Thynne was kill'd?

SP.SPEAKER: Watts.
SP.P: About eight a clock.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fra. Winn.
SP.P: Can you tell who brought the first news?

SP.SPEAKER: Watts.
SP.P: One of my Lady Seymour's Maids, who was telling the People of it below.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fra. Winn.
SP.P: Did you observe any body come to your Master's Lodgings afterwards?

SP.SPEAKER: Watts.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fra. Winn.
SP.P: Pray who came?

SP.SPEAKER: Watts.
SP.P: That Gentleman in the black Periwigg.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Williams.
SP.P: Pray in what Habit was he, and how came he in?

SP.SPEAKER: Watts.
SP.P: He came in a great Coat; I can't tell whether it was Cloath or Chamblet.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Williams,
SP.P: And what, did he speak to any Body, or go strait up?

SP.SPEAKER: Watts.
SP.P: No, he spoke to no Body, but went strait up Stairs.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Williams.
SP.P: Did he go up to your Master's Lodgings?

SP.SPEAKER: Watts.
SP.P: Yes, I believe so, but I stay'd below in the Shop.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Williams.
SP.P: How long did you stay in the Shop?

SP.SPEAKER: Watts.
SP.P: I stay'd there about half an Hour.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Williams.
SP.P: Did you leave him there?

SP.SPEAKER: Watts.
SP.P: Yes, I did.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Williams.
SP.P: Did he continue there all the time that you were in the House?

SP.SPEAKER: Watts.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Williams.
SP.P: What time did you go away?

SP.SPEAKER: Watts.
SP.P: About three Quarters of an Hour after that Gentleman came in.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fra. Withins.
SP.P: Do you remember you had any discourse with the Count, about riding on Sundays.

SP.SPEAKER: Watts.
SP.P: He asked me on Sunday in the Fore-noon, whether People were suffered to ride about the Streets on Horse-back on Sundays.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fra. Winn.
SP.P: This was that Sunday morning, was it?

SP.SPEAKER: Watts.
SP.P: Yes: he asked if they might be suffered to ride about the Streets on Sunday, I told him yes, before Sermon time and after Sermon time.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fra. Win.
SP.P: About what time of the day was it that he had this discourse?

SP.SPEAKER: Watts.
SP.P: About ten or eleven a Clock.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fra. Winn.
SP.P: Are you sure it was Sunday?

SP.SPEAKER: Watts.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fra. Winn.
SP.P: Then I ask you another Question; upon Sunday Morning or any other time, do you remember that the Polander was with the Count your Master?

SP.SPEAKER: Watts.
SP.P: He came in on the Saturday morning.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Williams.
SP.P: Was he in the Company or Presence of the Count?

SP.SPEAKER: Watts.
SP.P: I was above stairs when he came in.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fra. Winn.
SP.P: What do you know of any Sword that was delivered to him?

SP.SPEAKER: Watts.
SP.P: Upon the Sunday Morning there was a Sword brought to my Master's Lodgings, and my Master's man took it of me, and carried it up stairs, and this man, the Polander, afterwards had it below stairs.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Williams.
SP.P: When was this Sword brought to your Master's house?

SP.SPEAKER: Watts.
SP.P: It was on the Sunday morning.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Williams.
SP.P: What, the Cutler brought the Sword?

SP.SPEAKER: Watts.
SP.P: No, it was sent by a Porter from Mr. Hanson.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Williams.
SP.P: What Room was it carryed into when it was brought?

SP.SPEAKER: Watts.
SP.P: I think I did not carry it up: Yes truly, now I remember, I did, and deli∣vered it to my Master.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Williams.
SP.P: Pray what did the Count say to you?

SP.SPEAKER: Watts.
SP.P: I asked him if there needed an Answer of the Note I carryed with it, and he said no.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Williams.
SP.P: To whom was that Sword delivered afterwards?

SP.SPEAKER: Watts.
SP.P: It was brought down, and afterwards this Polander had it.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Williams.
SP.P: That man there?

SP.SPEAKER: Watts.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Williams.
SP.P: You say that the Sword was given to the Polander: Pray speak that the Jury may hear. Who brought down the Sword?

SP.SPEAKER: Watts.
SP.P: I saw it in the Polander's keeping when it was below, but I cannot say who brought it down.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fra. Winn.
SP.P: Where did the Polander dine on Saturday?

SP.SPEAKER: Watts.
SP.P: He dined with my Master's Man and I on Saturday.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fra. Winn.
SP.P: Where did he lye that Night? At whose Chamber?

SP.SPEAKER: Watts.
SP.P: At our Lodgings in the Garret, in my Master's Man's Chamber.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fran. Winn.
SP.P: What day was this, do you say?

SP.SPEAKER: Watts.
SP.P: Saturday.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Williams.
SP.P: When the Polander had the Sword, do you remember any Boots that he had under his Arm.

SP.SPEAKER: Watts.
SP.P: Yes, he had Boots under his Arm.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Williams.
SP.P: And he had the Sword with him when he went away?

SP.SPEAKER: Watts.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Williams.
SP.P: Had he any Coat?

SP.SPEAKER: Watts.
SP.P: Yes, a new Coat.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. VVilliams.
SP.P: Well, I ask you once more, what time of day was it that he went away with the Sword and the Boots?

SP.SPEAKER: Watts.
SP.P: It was in the Fore-noon.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. VVilliams.
SP.P: VVhat day of the Week?

SP.SPEAKER: Watts.
SP.P: Sunday morning.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Chief. Just.
SP.P: Ay, but your Doctor that you examined before, says, the Polander went away with him, and he was not there on Sunday Morning.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fra. VVinn.
SP.P: It is true, my Lord, it was too tender a point for the Doctor, he lyes under some Suspicion; and 'tis proximus ardet with him.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Chief. Just.
SP.P: Well call him again: Look you Doctor, you were asked before, and now you are asked again, were you at Count Coningsmark's Lodgings on the Sun∣day Morning?

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Harder.
SP.P: I cannot certainly tell.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Chief. Just.
SP.P: When did you see the Polander at the Count's Lodgings, and whe∣ther was it on Sunday morning?

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Harder.
SP.P: On Sunday Morning I did not see him. The only time was when I fetched him from my Lords, I have not seen him before nor since.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Chief Just.
SP.P: Then call up the Boy again. VVhere did the Polander dine on Sa∣turday?

SP.SPEAKER: VVatts.
SP.P: He dined with me and my Master's Man.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Chief. Just.
SP.P: VVhere?

SP.SPEAKER: Watts.
SP.P: Below, in the Kitchin of our Lodgings.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Ch. Just.
SP.P: Where lay the Polander that night?

SP.SPEAKER: Watts.
SP.P: He lay in our Garret.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Ch. Just.
SP.P: When went he from your Master's Lodgings?

SP.SPEAKER: Watts.
SP.P: On Sunday morning.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Williams.
SP.P: Had he an old Coat or a new Coat upon him?

SP.SPEAKER: Watts.
SP.P: He had a new Coat.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Ch. Just.
SP.P: Was the Doctor with him?

SP.SPEAKER: Watts.
SP.P: Yes, the Doctor went away with him.

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Harder.
SP.P: I have not seen the Polander above once in my Life.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fra. Win.
SP.P: But were you at the Count's on Sunday morning, or no, I ask you?

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Harder.
SP.P: I do not know whether it was Saturday or Sunday.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Ch. Just.
SP.P: But when you fetched him away, was it Saturday or Sunday morning?

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Harder
SP.P: My Lord, I can't very well remember.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Ch. Just.
SP.P: Had the Polander a Sword when you went away with him?

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Harder.
SP.P: I cannot positively say, but (as Travellers commonly have) he might have a Sword.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fra. Win.
SP.P: Now come to your self, and deal honestly, for you are upon your Oath; I ask you, friend, this, You say he might have a Sword, do you remember a pair of Boots?

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Harder.
SP.P: No, I do not.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fra. Win.
SP.P: Do you remember the Coat he had uppermost?

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Harder.
SP.P: Yes, he had something under his Coat, but I don't know it was Boots.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Ch. Baron.
SP.P: Had he a Buff-coat under his Campaigne?

SP.SPEAKER: Watts.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fra. Withins.
SP.P: Let me ask you one Question, young man, Do you remember you saw any Musquetoon in your Master's Lodging?

SP.SPEAKER: Watts.
SP.P: I did see a Gun there.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fra. Withins.
SP.P: When was that?

SP.SPEAKER: Watts.
SP.P: I saw it upon Saturday.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Williams.
SP.P: The Musquetoon or Gun that was in your Masters Lodgings, was it that which was bought by the Polander, or no?

SP.SPEAKER: Watts.
SP.P: I can't tell that.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Williams.
SP.P: Was it a long Piece or a short Piece?

SP.SPEAKER: Watts.
SP.P: It was not a short Piece.

SP.SPEAKER: L. C. Just.
SP.P: Did the Polander take it away with him?

SP.SPEAKER: Watts.
SP.P: No, not that I know of.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Williams.
SP.P: Now, young man, I would ask you as to Monday morning: About what time on Monday morning did you come to your Masters Lodgings?

SP.SPEAKER: Watts.
SP.P: It was between 7 and 8 a clock, a little after seven.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Williams.
SP.P: What condition was he in? was he in bed, or up?

SP.SPEAKER: Watts.
SP.P: He was up.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Williams.
SP.P: What was he doing? was he packing up?

SP.SPEAKER: Watts.
SP.P: Not that I see.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fra. Win.
SP.P: It was when he asked you about the Hubbub in the street; pray tell what he said to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Watts.
SP.P: He asked me what was the matter with the bustle in the street? and I told him that some were taken that had killed Esq Thynne; and I told him all the story as near as I could: He asked me when Esq Thynne was murdered? I told him the Night before, but I did not mind any thing that was done: But as I went down stairs, I met with a stranger, and he went up stairs, but I never saw my Master after, till he was ta∣ken.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fra Win.
SP.P: Did he ask you what Mr. Thynne was?

SP.SPEAKER: Watts.
SP.P: Yes, and I told him I heard he was a man of a great Estate, and well-be∣loved, and that the Duke of Monmouth was in the Coach but a little before, and if he had not gone out, he had been kill'd too.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fra. Win.
SP.P: VVhat said the Count to you, when you told him Mr. Thynne was well-beloved?

SP.SPEAKER: VVatts.
SP.P: He said nothing.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fra. Winn.
SP.P: Can you remember who it was came to your Master then?

SP.SPEAKER: Watts.
SP.P: I know the Man if I see him again.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fra. Winn.
SP.P: Do you know his Name?

SP.SPEAKER: Watts.
SP.P: No, I do not know his Name.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Williams.
SP.P: Were any of your Master's Goods carried away then?

SP.SPEAKER: Watts.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Williams.
SP.P: What Goods were carried away then?

SP.SPEAKER: Watts.
SP.P: Two Portmanteaus.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Williams.
SP.P: Who carried them away?

SP.SPEAKER: Watts.
SP.P: My Father carried them away.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Williams.
SP.P: What time was it?

SP.SPEAKER: Watts.
SP.P: Between 8 and 9 of the Clock.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fra. Winn.
SP.P: It was time to be gone. How parted you and your Master?

SP.SPEAKER: Watts.
SP.P: The Stranger did come in, and I never saw my Master afterwards.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fra. Winn.
SP.P: What, did your Master take no Leave, nor say any thing to you?

SP.SPEAKER: Watts.
SP.P: No.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fra. Winn.
SP.P: What kind of Periwigg had he when he went away?

SP.SPEAKER: Watts.
SP.P: He had a black Periwigg.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fran. Winn.
SP.P: What Cloaths.

SP.SPEAKER: Watts.
SP.P: A light coloured Suit, with gold Buttons.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Ch. Baron.
SP.P: Will the Count ask the Boy any Questions?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Craven.
SP.P: Did you see the Gun in the Room after the Polander was gone?

SP.SPEAKER: Watts.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Chief Just.
SP.P: 'Tis very plain, that this Gun was none of the Gun that did this Mischief, but the Gun the Polander brought over from beyond Sea.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fra Winn.
SP.P: Call the Boy's Father, Thomas Watts (who was sworn) How long have you known the Count?

SP.SPEAKER: T. Watts.
SP.P: I do not know him but as I have seen him.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fra. Winn.
SP.P: Were you employed to carry any thing for him?

SP.SPEAKER: T. Watts.
SP.P: Two or three times I was.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Williams.
SP.P: VVhen were you last employed by him?

SP.SPEAKER: T. Watts.
SP.P: The Morrow after the Murder was committed.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Williams.
SP.P: What Time in the morning was it?

SP.SPEAKER: T. Watts.
SP.P: It was between 8 and 9 of the Clock in the morning.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Williams.
SP.P: What was it you did for him?

SP.SPEAKER: T. Watts.
SP.P: I carried a Portmanteau, and a Portmanteau Trunck, and some other things.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Williams.
SP.P: Where were you directed to deliver these?

SP.SPEAKER: T. Watts.
SP.P: His Man told me they were to go to Windsor.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Williams.
SP.P: Well, tell the whole Story.

SP.SPEAKER: T. Watts.
SP.P: He bid me carry them to Charing Cross, that they might be put into the Coach there. But when he came to Charing Cross, a Coach-man and he had some Words, and he bid him open his Boot, and then he took the things from me, and put them into the Coach.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Chief Just.
SP.P: Who was it that told you they were to go to Windsor?

SP.SPEAKER: T. Watts.
SP.P: It was his Man.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fran. Winn.
SP.P: I would ask you, Sir, when was the first time you knew the Count?

SP.SPEAKER: T. Watts.
SP.P: It was ten or eleven days before.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Francis Winning.
SP.P: What was the occasion that brought you acquainted with him?

SP.SPEAKER: T. Watts.
SP.P: I was Dr. Frederick's Porter, and he sent me to carry some things to the Count.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Williams.
SP.P: Was it your Son that waited upon him?

SP.SPEAKER: T. VVats.
SP.P: Yes. For when I brought the things, they said they had forgot to give me a Sword which I was to carry with the things; and I said, that I had a Boy that I would send, and I did so, and so they took a Liking to the Boy.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. VVilliams.
SP.P: What was the Agreement for your Son's Service?

SP.SPEAKER: T. Watts.
SP.P: Six pence a Day, and his Victuals.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fran. Winn.
SP.P: What was the man's name (as you remember) that gave you the things to carry to the Coach, which were said to go to Windsor?

SP.SPEAKER: T. Watts.
SP.P: I can't tell his Name.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Williams.
SP.P: He that pinched and pushed you back, and took the things from you and put them into the Coach?

SP.SPEAKER: L. C. Justice.
SP.P: Did you see the Count that Morning?

SP.SPEAKER: T. Watts.
SP.P: No, I did not see him.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Williams.
SP.P: Have you been laboured and sought to by any body to con∣ceal your Boy, that he should not be brought at this Tryal?

SP.SPEAKER: T. Watts.
SP.P: No, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Williams.
SP.P: Had you no endeavours used with you about it?

SP.SPEAKER: T. Watts.
SP.P: No.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Williams.
SP.P: Did no body speak of any such thing to you?

SP.SPEAKER: T. Watts.
SP.P: No.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Williams.
SP.P: Did any Merchant or any body send to you about this Body, to take him into Service?

SP.SPEAKER: T. Watts.
SP.P: There was a Merchant that would have helped the Boy to a place on Saturday last, but the Persons that would have procured it were about it a good while ago.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Williams.
SP.P: Call Derick Raynes, and Richard Chappel.
(who were Sworn and Raynes stood up.)
When did you see the Count, the Prisoner at the Bar?

SP.SPEAKER: Raynes.
SP.P: On Monday in the Afternoon.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Williams.
SP.P: What time was it in the Afternoon?

SP.SPEAKER: Raynes.
SP.P: In the Evening.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Williams.
SP.P: Where was it?

SP.SPEAKER: Raynes.
SP.P: At my House.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Williams.
SP.P: Where is that?

SP.SPEAKER: Raynes.
SP.P: At Rotherith.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Williams.
SP.P: How came the Count to your House?

SP.SPEAKER: Raynes.
SP.P: I know not, I was not at home when he came.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Williams.
SP.P: Pray when you saw him, had he his own Hair or a Perriwig, or how was he habited?

SP.SPEAKER: Raynes.
SP.P: He had black Hair then.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Williams.
SP.P: How long did he continue at your House?

SP.SPEAKER: Raynes.
SP.P: From Monday till Thursday Morning.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Williams.
SP.P: Was he privately there or publickly?

SP.SPEAKER: Raynes.
SP.P: He walked up and down the House.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fran. Win.
SP.P: What Country-man are you?

SP.SPEAKER: Raynes.
SP.P: I am a Sweed.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fran. Winn.
SP.P: What became of him after Thursday?

SP.SPEAKER: Raynes.
SP.P: On Thursday Morning he took Water and went to Deptford.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fran. Winn.
SP.P: What way did he go, by Boat, or how?

SP.SPEAKER: Raynes.
SP.P: A Waterman carried him.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Williams.
SP.P: Pray what did the Count say to you about his coming in a dis∣guise to your House?

SP.SPEAKER: Raynes.
SP.P: I knew nothing at all. I came late home, and when I came to know of him what he was, then he told me that he was Count Coningsmark.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Williams.
SP.P: What did he say to you when you discovered that he was the Count? What did he tell you of his business?

SP.SPEAKER: Raynes.
SP.P: He said nothing; but that he was desirous to go to Graves-End.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fran. Winn.
SP.P: Upon your Oath, Sir, did you furnish him with any Clothes?

SP.SPEAKER: Raynes.
SP.P: Yes, I lent him a Coat.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fran. Winn.
SP.P: What say you to a black Suit?

SP.SPEAKER: Raynes.
SP.P: The black Suit did not belong to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fran. Winn.
SP.P: What say you to a Velvet Cap?

SP.SPEAKER: Raynes.
SP.P: I helped him to a Coat, Stockings, and Shoes.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fran. Winn.
SP.P: Then I ask you, what did he declare to you?

SP.SPEAKER: Raynes.
SP.P: Why, he did desire to have those Clothes.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fran. Winn.
SP.P: You are an honest man, tell the truth.

SP.SPEAKER: Raynes.
SP.P: He declared nothing to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fran. Winn.
SP.P: When you dressed him, why did he put on that habit?

SP.SPEAKER: Raynes.
SP.P: He thought his own Clothes were too cold to go upon the water.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fran. Winn.
SP.P: Had he no Clothes before?

SP.SPEAKER: Raynes.
SP.P: Yes, he had.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Williams.
SP.P: You had the warmer Coat, had you?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fran. Winn.
SP.P: Did he desire you to let him have your Clothes, because he was in trouble?

SP.SPEAKER: Raynes.
SP.P: He desired a Coat of me, and a pair of Stockings to keep his Leggs warm, and when he had got them, his own Shoes would not come on, so I lent him a pair of Shoes.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fran. Winn.
SP.P: I do ask you, did he declare the reason why he would have those Cloathes, was, because he would not be known?

SP.SPEAKER: Raynes.
SP.P: He said he was afraid of coming into trouble.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fran. Winn.
SP.P: Why were you unwilling to tell this?

SP.SPEAKER: Raynes.
SP.P: Assoon as I came to know he was the man, I told him he should not stay in my House.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fran. Win.
SP.P: Did you lend him those Clothes or sell them?

SP.SPEAKER: Raynes.
SP.P: I lent him them.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fran. Winn.
SP.P: Had you them again?

SP.SPEAKER: Raynes.
SP.P: No, I had not.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fran. Winn.
SP.P: Are you paid for them or no?

SP.SPEAKER: Raynes.
SP.P: No, my Ship lyes at the Key, and I came home late in the Evening, and found him there.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fran. Winn.
SP.P: Set up Richard Chappel.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Williams.
SP.P: When did you first see that Gentleman?

SP.SPEAKER: Chappel.
SP.P: On Thursday Morning at Ten of the Clock.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Williams.
SP.P: Where?

SP.SPEAKER: Chappel.
SP.P: At Rotherith.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Williams.
SP.P: How came you to him? who brought you?

SP.SPEAKER: Chappel.
SP.P: That Man.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Williams.
SP.P: What were you to do with him?

SP.SPEAKER: Chappel.
SP.P: To carry him to Graves-End.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Williams.
SP.P: Do you Row in a pair of Oars, or a Sculler?

SP.SPEAKER: Chappel.
SP.P: A Sculler.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Williams.
SP.P: Whither did you carry the Count that day?

SP.SPEAKER: Chappel.
SP.P: To Deptford.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Williams.
SP.P: Whither the next day?

SP.SPEAKER: Chappel.
SP.P: To Greenwich.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Williams.
SP.P: And whither then?

SP.SPEAKER: Chappel.
SP.P: To Greenhithe, and then the next day to Graves-End.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Williams.
SP.P: Was he in the same Clothes all the while?

SP.SPEAKER: Chappel.
SP.P: Yes, all the while.

SP.SPEAKER: L. C. Baron.
SP.P: Were you hired to wait upon him all that time?

SP.SPEAKER: Chappel.
SP.P: Yes, I was to have 5 s. every 24 hours.

SP.SPEAKER: L. C. Baron.
SP.P: Was he alone?

SP.SPEAKER: Chappel.
SP.P: No, this man was with him.

SP.SPEAKER: L. C. Justice.
SP.P: Did he go in the Sculler with him?

SP.SPEAKER: Chappel.
SP.P: Yes, to Deptford.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Williams.
SP.P: Well, now we will call the Gentleman that seized him at the Water-side at Graves-End.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fran. Winn.
SP.P: What did the Count call himself? What profession did he tell you he was of?

SP.SPEAKER: Chappel.
SP.P: He told me he was a Merchant.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fran. Winn.
SP.P: Did he say he was a Jeweller upon your Oath?

SP.SPEAKER: Chappel.
SP.P: Yes, he said he had bought Jewels.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fran. Winn.
SP.P: Where is Mr. Gibbons, and Mr. John Kid? who were Sworn and Mr. Kid stood up.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Williams.
SP.P:
Mr. Kid, pray Sir, will you acquaint my Lord and the Jury,
in what Condition you found the Count at Graves-End. Tell the whole story, and speak aloud, that all may hear you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Kid.
SP.P: I had some Information upon Friday Night of him.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Willians.
SP.P: Of whom, and what?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Kid.
SP.P: Of the Count where he was. So I made it my Business to in∣quire into it. On Saturday in the Afternoon a Gentleman came to me, and gave me certain Information where he thought that Gentleman the Count was. This Gentleman coming to me said, Mr. Thynne is a stranger to me, but said he, I would not have Mr. Thynn's Blood lye at my door. This same person who is put out in the Gazette, I believe, is at a Neighbours house of mine. Says he, I desire you to be private in it, because it may do you a prejudice: so we went into a Coach at Charing-Cross to go to a Justice of Peace; I did not know where Sir John Reresby lived, but inquired of Mr. Gibbon's, who told me, but he was not at home, and Mr. Bridgman was not at home; So we went to the Recor∣der, and there we had a Warrant, and then I came by water to Rotherith, and this same Raynes that was Examined, and his Wife where he lay, were gone to Greenwich to carry his Clothes, a grey Suit, and other Clothes that he had left. So going down to Greenwich we called every Boat that was upon the River aboard of us, to know whence they came. And we had taken her Sister along with us, and she called out her Sisters name Mall Raynes, and her Bro∣thers name Derrick Raynes, and so at last we got the Boat wherein they were on board us. And we asked the man, what he had done with the Gentleman that lay at his House? he declared, he was gone away he did not know whi∣ther. So I went back again to this Gentleman that gave me this first Informa∣tion, who did go to him as a Neighbour, to know whither he was gone, and where he was to be found, and where he would Land. So he declared the particulars, That if we missed him that Night, we should have him in the Hope upon Monday Morning, upon a Vessel that was to be cleared on Monday Morning. So upon Sunday Night coming to Graves-end about 8 or 9 a Clock, or there abouts, there he landed. There were 13 or 14 Swedes at the same House where he was to Land. So we thought it convenient to take him at his first land∣ing, for fear of further danger. So I stay'd at the Red Lyon Back-Stayres, and he landed at the Fore-stayres where the Watermen were. As soon as he was laid hold of, I came to him, said I, your Lordship shall not want for any thing that is convenient. He desired to know, whether I knew him? I told him; Yes, and that his name was Count Coningsmarke. That is my Name, says he; I do not deny it. So the Maior came and the Custom-House Officers Searched him? and found nothing at all of any Arms about him. He desired he might be used like a Gentleman, and so he was, for there was no abuse given to him, as I know of. Coming up the River, the most of my discourse was about Martial Af∣fairs; a Serjeant that had the Command of a File of Musqueteers, which the Deputy-Governour sent to guard the Count to White-Hall, a Gentleman sit∣ting there by me was asking me concerning Mr. Thynne's Murder; I told him, that I was at New-gate on Friday, and there I saw those that had done that barbarous Fact. With that, my Lord asked, what Lodgings there were in New-gate. And whether the Captain had a good Lodging? I told him a very good one. He asked me, whether he confessed any thing? I told him he had confessed some particulars; And said I, 'tis the most barbarous thing that ever was done. Certainly, says my Lord, this Mr. Thynne must have Cor∣respondence and Commerce with some Lady that this Captain knew, that belonged to the Court, or he would never have done it. As for the Polander, I told him, that he had confessed, he wept mightily. With that my Lord seem∣ed very much concerned, and took up his Clothes and bit them, and sat awhile up, but was very much discomposed, and then desired to lye down.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fran. Winn.
SP.P: That was, when you told him, the Polander had confessed.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Kid.
SP.P: Yes; my Lord was mightily altered in his Countenance.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fran. Winn.
SP.P: Did you at the first time that you seized him charge him with the Murder?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Kid.
SP.P: No, I did not.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fran. Winn.
SP.P: Was he in a Black Perriwig?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Kid.
SP.P: His Cap fell off, and his Perriwig, just as I came to him.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fran. Winn.
SP.P: Set up Mr. Gibbons. Pray will you tell what passed.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Gibbons.
SP.P: My Lord, Assoon as ever he came to shore, I walked by him, and gave him a little kind of a justle, and my reason was, to see whether he had not a black Coat under his Campaign: I walked close to him just in this man∣ner, as he walked along, so he turns about again, and went down to the Water side, and asked the Water-men, Watermen, Have you stowed your Boat? he answered, Yes; Then come away said he; so soon as he came back again, I catched him fast hold by the Arm, and the first word he said to me was, What do you come to Rob me? said I, my Lord, you are my Prisoner, and I told him I was the King's Messenger that had waited there several days for him; holding of him very hard whether, that was the occasion of it, or the Waterman that were on the other side of him, he dropped down his Sword between his Leggs; but when I named his Name, he gave a little start and his Perriwig dropped off of his Face. We went up the Street to the Mayor, and the People crowding about us were very rude and very rugged, and he desired he might be well used. We did all we could to keep the People from him; we went up to the Mayor's House, and when we came there, I desired he might be searched, whether he had any Arms; He said, he had none, and there was none.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fran. Winn.
SP.P: When you had the Custody of him, whither did you carry him?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Gibbons.
SP.P: We carried him to the Mayor's House, and after we removed him from his House to an Inn.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fran. Winn.
SP.P: What did you do the next Day?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Gibbons.
SP.P: We stayed there about some 2 or 3 Hours. After an hour or half an hours time, near upon an hour, my Lord came to me, and asked me my Name; and he said, the reason was, that after his Trouble was over, he would give me thanks for my Civility to him. Captain Sinkleer, who stood by, gave him my Name before I could, that it was Gibbons. Yes said I, my Name is Gib∣bons, and I belong to the Duke of Monmouth: why says he, the Duke of Mon∣mouth has no Command now, and therefore how could I take him by his Order? My Lord, said I, I do not apprehend you by his Order; you have killed a very good Friend of mine, and had not Providence ordered it otherwise, you had like to have killed a more particular Friend, and a Master: So my Lord he seemed to be very sorry at that; but says he, I don't think they would have done any harm to the Duke of Monmouth.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fran. Winn.
SP.P: What else did he say?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Gibbons.
SP.P: I think I have told you all that is Material.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fran. Winn.
SP.P: Were you in the Boat at any time, and gave him any Ac∣count of the Man's having Confessed; what did he say to it?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Gibbons.
SP.P: Sir, I was not there, nor I did not come up in the same Boat with him.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Williams.
SP.P: Did he mention any thing about a stain to his Blood?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Gibbons.
SP.P: I ask your pardon, he did so.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Williams.
SP.P: What did he say?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Gibbons.
SP.P: Says he, it is a Stain upon my Blood; but one good Action in the Wars, or one Lodging upon a Counterscarp will wash away all that.

SP.SPEAKER: L. C. Justice.
SP.P: What did he say was a Stain upon his Blood?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Gibbons.
SP.P: My Lord, If you please, I will tell you. As I said, he asked me my Name, because he would come to give me thanks for my Civility after his Trouble was over; the Captain being quicker than I, told him my Name: Yes, Sir said I, 'tis Gibbons, and I belong to the Duke of Monmouth; said he, he has no Command now, how could you come upon his Order; said I, I do not come upon his Command, but you have killed a very good Friend of mine, and a Country-man, and if Providence had not ordered it otherwise, you had killed a more particular Friend of mine, and a Master, that I had served many years; said he, I don't think they would have done the Duke of Monmouth any Injury: after that he walked up and down a while, and then said he, 'tis a stain upon my Blood; but one good Action in the Wars, or Lodging upon a Counter∣scarp will wash away all that. The Mayor was in the Room, and several o∣thers.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fran. Winn.
SP.P: Pray Sir, one thing more, when you did speak to him of Con∣fession, did he say any thing to you about Captain Ʋratz?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Gibbons.
SP.P: Sir, he was only asking of me how things were, what the people said or some such thing? I was not forward to tell him at first, but afterwards I did tell him, that the Captain had made a Confession, though it was a thing I did not know then. Says he, I do not believe the Captain would confess any thing.

SP.SPEAKER: L. C. Justice.
SP.P: Did he say so?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Gibbons.
SP.P: Yes, he did to the best of my remembrance.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Fran. Winn.
SP.P: We have done with our evidence, my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: L. C. Justice.
SP.P: My Lord Coningsmarke, will you ask him any thing?

SP.SPEAKER: Count Coningsmarke.
SP.P: No.

SP.SPEAKER: L. C. Justice.
SP.P: Then the next thing is, you heard the Evidence that is given against you. Now you must come to your defence; I will put you in mind of some things, my Lord, which things it will concern you to give some Accompt of. It is here laid to your Charge, That you were Accessory to this Murder of Mr. Thynne; and that you were the person that directed and designed it.
